context: Image Media thumbnail alt text cannot be changed without reuploading the image

models.text: Users with disabilities relying on screen readers may be unable to accurately describe images displayed as thumbnails due to the lack of editable alternative text. This creates a barrier to understanding the content and effectively utilizing the image media.

The system prevents users from editing the alt text of image media thumbnails without re‑uploading the image, which blocks the provision of accurate, descriptive text alternatives for screen reader users and other assistive technologies.

The current implementation of Image Media in Drupal does not allow users to directly modify the alt text for the thumbnail image displayed for a media item. To update the alt text, the image must be re-uploaded. This presents a barrier for users who rely on accurate alt text for understanding the image's context, especially when the thumbnail is used as a visual cue or identifier in lists or grids. This also makes it difficult to correct errors in the original alt text without a complete media update.
Error

Users relying on screen readers may be unable to accurately describe images displayed as thumbnails due to the inability to modify the associated alternative text. This creates a barrier to understanding the content and effectively utilizing the image media.

context: Automated A11y tests in PHPUnit

models.text: Users with disabilities may encounter difficulties accessing content if the automated A11y tests in PHPUnit do not adequately identify and report accessibility issues within the application. This could lead to a reduced user experience for individuals relying on assistive technologies.
No accessibility barrier is identified in the current issue description; the report appears to be a feature request for adding automated accessibility tests to PHPUnit.

The absence of automated accessibility tests within the PHPUnit test suite poses a significant risk of introducing accessibility barriers into the Drupal codebase. Without these tests, developers may inadvertently introduce code that violates WCAG guidelines, leading to a degraded user experience for individuals with disabilities.
Error

context: Pager template fails accessibility tests for Ellipsis ("...")

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty interpreting the pagination controls within the Pager template due to the absence of appropriate visual cues and semantic structure. This can impede their ability to navigate and understand the number of pages available.
Error

The ellipsis used in the pagination component is being read out by screen readers as a separate element (e.g., “ellipsis” or “dot dot dot”), which interrupts the logical sequence of page numbers and can confuse users who rely on assistive technology.

Users of assistive technologies may hear or interpret the ellipsis (“…”) in the pagination control as an ambiguous or unexplained element, leading to confusion about omitted pages and hindering navigation. The ellipsis lacks an accessible description, so screen‑reader users cannot understand its purpose, potentially causing navigation errors.

The pager component utilizes an ellipsis ("...") to indicate skipped page numbers. This implementation fails accessibility tests because the ellipsis provides no semantic information or context for users of assistive technologies. Without additional information, users are unable to understand the relationship between the displayed pages and the skipped content, potentially leading to confusion and hindering their ability to navigate the site effectively.
Error

The ellipsis ("…") used in the pager control is not properly conveyed to assistive technologies, potentially causing confusion or omission of page navigation information for users with visual or cognitive impairments.

Users with screen reader support may encounter difficulty understanding the pagination controls if the ellipsis (...) is not appropriately implemented for accessibility. This prevents users from determining the total number of pages and potentially leads to confusion or difficulty navigating the content.

The presence of radio buttons, designated as required for form submission, lack the HTML "required" attribute. This omission prevents assistive technologies from properly communicating the required status to users, creating a barrier to form completion for individuals with disabilities.
Error
The form’s radio group lacks a required indicator, so users cannot know that a selection is mandatory, which may lead to incomplete submissions or confusion for those using assistive technologies.

Users relying on screen readers may not be alerted that a radio button group is required, potentially leading to incomplete or incorrect form submissions. This impacts the ability to ensure data integrity and fulfills WCAG 2.2 requirements for form validation.

context: Use ARIA disclosure pattern for submenu buttons in vertical toolbar orientation

context: Assess JavaScript behaviours for WCAG 2.1 Pointer Cancellation

models.text: Users relying on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may experience difficulty interacting with interactive elements if JavaScript behaviours related to pointer cancellation are not implemented accessibly. This can lead to a degraded user experience and potential exclusion.

Users may unintentionally activate elements during touch or pointer interactions because the site's JavaScript does not properly cancel pending actions when the user changes direction or starts scrolling, leading to errors and frustration.

This means that certain interactive elements might require users to complete actions (e.g., pressing and releasing a button) within a defined area, without the option to abort or undo the action upon release outside of the target area. This can create barriers for users with motor impairments who may accidentally trigger actions.
Error

Users relying on keyboard navigation or assistive technologies may experience difficulty interacting with interactive elements if JavaScript behaviours during pointer cancellation are not properly handled. This can lead to a loss of control and frustration, preventing users from completing tasks.

context: W3C Validation: required attribute not allowed on fieldset tag

models.text: The issue reports a validation error regarding the `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` tag. The presence of a non‑standard `required` attribute on a `<fieldset>` element is a markup validation error. Screen readers and other assistive technologies ignore this attribute, so it does not directly create an accessibility barrier. However, the invalid markup may cause confusion during development or lead to unintended form‑validation behavior, potentially impacting the user experience.

The `required` attribute has been incorrectly applied to the `fieldset` element, resulting in a W3C validation error. The `required` attribute is intended for form elements like `input`, `select`, and `textarea`, not grouping elements like `fieldset`. This does not directly create an accessibility barrier, but it indicates a semantic error in the code and can confuse assistive technologies if they attempt to process the attribute incorrectly.

Users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies may encounter confusion when interacting with form fields on translated content. If field labels remain in the original language or are not properly marked with language information, assistive technology may announce the wrong language, hindering comprehension and increasing the risk of input errors.

When a translated node contains field labels that remain in the original language (i.e., are not translated), these labels are not identified with the appropriate language tag. This can cause screen readers to pronounce the labels incorrectly, hindering comprehension for users who rely on screen readers to understand the content.
Error

Users relying on screen readers may experience confusion and difficulty understanding the purpose of form fields when translations of nodes lack proper indication of “Language of Parts” for field labels. This impacts the user’s ability to correctly interact with the form and complete tasks.

context: Provide screen-reader feedback when Views UI filterable options are updated

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may miss updates to Views UI filterable options due to a lack of auditory feedback. This creates a barrier to understanding the current filter state and selecting appropriate options, potentially leading to inaccurate data analysis or missed opportunities.

The lack of screen‑reader feedback when filterable options in the Views UI are updated prevents users of assistive technologies from knowing that the list has changed. This barrier can cause confusion and hinder navigation, as users are unable to detect dynamic content updates that are otherwise visible on the screen.

When filtering options within the Views UI, screen reader users are not informed when the results of applying a filter are loaded and updated. This lack of feedback creates a usability barrier, as users are left unaware of the status of their filtering actions, potentially leading to confusion and inefficient task completion.
Error

Users who rely on screen readers may miss updates to Views UI filterable options. This creates a barrier to understanding the current state of the filtered content, potentially leading to inaccurate decisions or a frustrated user experience.

context: [meta] Track progress in WCAG 2.0 conformance

models.text: The issue description lacks detail regarding a specific accessibility barrier. It simply states a need to track WCAG 2.0 conformance. context: image field alt help/description should distinguish between decorative & meaningful images

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience confusion when presented with images lacking appropriate alternative text descriptions. Decorative images, which contribute to the visual aesthetic but do not convey essential information, should be marked as such to prevent screen readers from announcing them unnecessarily, thereby disrupting the user experience.

Users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies may receive irrelevant or missing information if image alt text is not correctly marked as decorative or meaningful. Without clear guidance in the image field, authors may unintentionally add descriptive alt to decorative images or leave alt empty for meaningful images, causing confusion or loss of content context.

The current image field configuration in Drupal does not provide adequate guidance to content authors on differentiating between decorative and meaningful images, specifically in the alt text field's help text. This lack of clarity can lead to inconsistent and incorrect alt text implementation, resulting in accessibility barriers for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies.
Error

Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty distinguishing between images intended for informational content and purely decorative images. This can lead to redundant auditory descriptions of decorative images, increasing cognitive load and reducing the efficiency of screen reader navigation.

context: Improve accessibility of layout preview icons

models.text: Users with disabilities who rely on visual cues or screen reader magnification may find it difficult to accurately interpret the function and purpose of layout preview icons. This lack of clear visual information can hinder their ability to understand and utilize the layout preview feature effectively.

Users who rely on assistive technologies cannot understand or interact with the layout preview icons because the icons lack descriptive text or accessible names, causing confusion and preventing users from selecting or identifying the intended layout options.

The layout preview icons lack sufficient semantic information or alternative text, presenting a barrier for users who are visually impaired or rely on assistive technologies. This prevents users from understanding the layout structure being represented and making informed decisions about their content organization.
Error

Users with disabilities who rely on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding or interacting with layout preview icons if they lack sufficient alternative text or are not programmatically exposed to assistive technology. This can impede the user's ability to effectively visualize and navigate the intended layout.

context: In WYSIWYG embed modal for existing images, the alt text field should have a default value instead of placeholder text

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the purpose of the alt text field within the WYSIWYG embed modal for existing images. The current placeholder text does not provide sufficient context, hindering users' ability to accurately provide or understand the alt text, potentially leading to inaccurate descriptions and a reduced understanding of the image's role in the content.

The alt text field in the embed modal for existing images displays placeholder text but does not pre‑populate with the image’s current alt text. Screen‑reader users and other assistive technology users cannot see or confirm the existing alt text, which can lead to incorrect or missing alt attributes and ultimately reduce the accessibility of the image content.

The alt text field within the image embed modal of the WYSIWYG editor uses placeholder text instead of a default value. This presents an accessibility barrier as placeholder text disappears when the field is focused or populated, making it difficult for users, particularly those with cognitive disabilities, to remember what information is required.
Error

Users relying on screen readers may find the placeholder text in the alt text field of the WYSIWYG embed modal for existing images confusing and misleading. The lack of a default value prevents users from immediately understanding the image's content, potentially hindering navigation and comprehension.

context: Password suggestions are hidden from screenreaders

This creates a usability barrier for individuals who rely on screen readers to interact with the interface.

Users who rely on screen readers may be unable to access password suggestions provided within the application. This prevents users from receiving assistance with creating strong passwords, potentially impacting security and usability for these individuals.

context: Media alt text not available in Views

Users relying on screen readers may be unable to access alternative text descriptions for media content displayed within the Views interface. This prevents users from understanding the content and purpose of the media, creating a barrier to information access.

context: Add support for tables with two headers in views table display

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience confusion and difficulty interpreting tabular data when tables display two header rows. This could lead to a reduced understanding of the table’s structure and content, impacting data comprehension.

context: [Regression] Password recommendations are not being announced to screenreader users

models.text: Screenreader users are unable to receive audible guidance regarding password recommendations, potentially hindering their ability to create secure passwords and increasing their risk of compromise. This represents a barrier to effective user experience and accessibility.

Screen reader users do not hear the dynamic password recommendations that appear while creating or changing a password, limiting their ability to see suggested improvements or rules for a strong password.

Password recommendations provided by the system are not being programmatically exposed to assistive technologies, preventing screen reader users from receiving this information. This creates a barrier for users who rely on screen readers to create secure passwords.

context: Find a way to differentiate different media types in the administrative media library grid view

The current administrative media library grid view lacks sufficient visual or textual cues to differentiate between various media types (e.g., images, documents, videos). This presents a barrier for users, especially those with visual impairments or cognitive disabilities, who rely on such distinctions to efficiently locate and manage media assets.

Users relying on screen readers may struggle to easily identify and differentiate media types within the administrative media library grid view. context: Add GUI to configure the site's logo alt attribute

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may be unable to easily update the alternative text description for the site’s logo. This directly impacts the ability to provide meaningful context for users who rely on visual cues, potentially hindering comprehension and navigation.

The logo image on the site lacks a meaningful alt attribute (or the alt attribute cannot be configured), so screen‑reader users receive no information about the logo’s purpose or meaning. This omission can cause confusion and prevent users from understanding or navigating the site.

The website logo's `alt` attribute is not configurable, preventing users from ensuring its text alternative accurately reflects its purpose and context on the site. This creates a potential barrier for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies to understand the logo's meaning and function.

context: Olivero: messages icons accessibility

The message icons in Olivero’s notification component lack accessible text or are not properly hidden from assistive technologies, preventing screen‑reader users from knowing the type or content of each message.

context: Allow content authors to define location for long description in CKEditor image plugin

This limits the ability to provide captions for prerecorded audio‑visual content, which may hinder users who rely on captions, such as deaf or hard‑of‑hearing individuals, from accessing the content.

context: Update audio and video file field formatters to include track elements

models.text: Users relying on screen reader technology may be unable to correctly identify and select individual audio and video tracks within media files. This limits their ability to customize their viewing or listening experience and potentially miss important content.

The lack of `<track>` elements in the rendered audio and video fields means that captions or subtitles are not available to users who rely on them. This limits comprehension of prerecorded media for people with hearing impairments, or in situations where audio cannot be heard.

context: Provide authors with tools to manage transcripts and captions/subtitles for local video and audio

context: Datetime and Datelist elements should render as fieldsets

The absence of a <fieldset> around datetime and datelist form controls removes the visual and screen‑reader indication that these inputs belong to a logical group. Users with assistive technology therefore lack clear context, making it difficult to understand how the inputs relate to one another and to the overall form.

Datetime and Datelist elements are not rendered within fieldsets, which makes it difficult for assistive technology users to understand the relationships between the individual fields within the date and time input groups. This can lead to confusion and errors when filling out forms.

Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between datetime and datelist elements if they are not rendered with appropriate semantic structure. This can impede the ability to accurately interpret and interact with the form controls.

context: radio buttons and checkboxes should be grouped by fieldsets

models.text: Users with disabilities, particularly those using screen readers, may experience difficulty understanding the relationship between radio buttons and checkboxes when they are not grouped within a fieldset. This can lead to confusion regarding the intended selection and potential errors when completing forms.

This lack of contextual grouping can lead to confusion, misinterpretation, and errors, particularly for screen‑reader users who rely on group labels to navigate related controls.

Radio buttons and checkboxes are not properly grouped using `<fieldset>` and `<legend>` elements. context: Olivero theme should place comment titles above authoring info in comment.html.twig in order to enhance screenreader experience

models.text: Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the structure of comment threads when authoring information and comment titles are presented in the same block. This can lead to confusion regarding the hierarchy and relationships within the comment data.

The current comment markup places the comment title after the authoring information in the DOM. Screen reader users therefore encounter the author details before the comment content, which breaks the expected reading sequence and can cause confusion or missed context. This ordering issue affects users who rely on assistive technology to navigate and understand the flow of a comment section.

In the Olivero theme, comment titles are located below the comment authoring information (e.g., author name and date). This order can negatively impact the screen reader user experience, as the title provides a clear indication of the comment's subject matter, which should be announced prior to the authoring information.

Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty understanding the hierarchy of information within the comment section due to the current layout of authoring information appearing above the comment title. This impacts the user’s ability to quickly identify the context of the comment.

context: Allow a custom HTML element to be selected for a grouping field

Users navigating with assistive technologies may not receive clear group context because the custom element does not provide native grouping semantics or an accessible name, leading to confusion when moving between related form controls.

The current implementation lacks the ability to define the HTML element used for grouping fields, potentially hindering semantic structure and accessibility. A pre-defined element might not always be appropriate for all content, potentially causing semantic errors or forcing the use of ARIA attributes for correction. This lack of flexibility can negatively impact users of assistive technology who rely on semantic HTML for understanding the structure and relationships within the content.

Users may encounter difficulty understanding and interacting with a grouping field that accepts a custom HTML element if the interaction isn't clearly conveyed to assistive technology users. context: Umami theme ignores placeholders and HTML replaced elements when checking for empty regions

This can lead to inaccurate announcements about the state of interactive elements, preventing users from effectively interacting with the interface.

The theme fails to account for placeholder text and replaced elements when determining whether a region contains content. Because placeholder attributes are not announced by screen readers and replaced elements may lack accessible text, users of assistive technology receive no instructions or visible content for those form controls, resulting in confusion and impaired interaction.

The Umami theme incorrectly identifies regions as empty when they contain placeholders or HTML replaced elements, such as images or other dynamically rendered content. This can lead to content being unnecessarily hidden from users, potentially impacting access to essential information or functionality.
Error

Users relying on screen readers may experience inaccurate detection of empty regions within the Umami theme due to the theme’s handling of placeholders and replaced elements. context: Assess accessibility of Claro in High Contrast AKA forced colors mode

The Claro theme may not render properly in high‑contrast or forced‑colors mode, potentially resulting in insufficient contrast, missing focus outlines, or inaccessible UI components for users who rely on these modes.

context: [Meta] Track CSS forced-color standardization and browser support

models.text: Users with color vision deficiencies may experience difficulty perceiving content due to the potential for forced color schemes. The issue highlights inconsistent implementation of CSS forced‑color mode across browsers, which can prevent users who rely on high‑contrast settings from seeing UI components with adequate contrast.

This issue tracks the standardization and browser support for CSS forced-color modes. context: Fieldset should not create title element when title is empty

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. …Activate any CKEditor element that has a "balloon" interface.
2. …Click anywhere outside of the balloon interface to dismiss it
3. …The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### ✔️ Expected result

The balloon interface is dismissed on mouse up or finger-lift.

### ❌ Actual result

The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### Background
This constitutes a failure a Level A Success Criterion as documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html

The specific failure is documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101 :

> The objective of this Failure is to describe situations where:
> 
>     Controls are set to activate functionality on the down-event of a pointer;
>     No further mechanism to abort or undo is available;
>     The up-event does not reverse the outcome of the activation;
>     It is not essential for the functionality to execute and complete on the down-event.

### Proposed resolution
Change the behavior so that balloons are dismissed on the "up" event, rather than the "down" event.

models.text: The barrier occurs when CKEditor’s balloon UI dismisses on the pointer‑down (or key‑down) event instead of on pointer‑up, causing accidental closure and violating WCAG 2.5.2’s pointer‑cancellation requirement. Users with motor impairments or those who inadvertently touch a button may trigger an unintended dismissal, undermining control over the interface.
Users who tap or press keys to interact with the CKEditor balloon may inadvertently dismiss it at the moment of the press, causing loss of context or unsaved content and hindering task completion.

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Select "Bookmarks" in the balloon panel

The screen reader should announce:

- List
- with 2 entries
- Heritage button

### ❌ Actual result

The Screen reader announces:

- List
- Heritage button

### ❓ Possible solution

- Number of elements = 0: Display only an informational text (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` → In screen readers, the button is announced without a list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute → In screen readers, the list is announced correctly as a list.

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: In CKEditor 5’s link editing interface, the “Bookmarks” panel presents its items as an unordered list. When multiple bookmark items are present, the list (<ul>) and its list items (<li>) are assigned `role="presentation"`. This removes the list semantics from the markup, causing screen readers to announce only the list container and the “Heritage” button, but not the individual bookmark entries. Consequently, users of assistive technology cannot access the list items, violating the requirement that information conveyed through structural elements must be perceivable.

The screen reader fails to announce the single bookmark entry in the CKEditor link editor. When only one bookmark is present, the list and list item are given `role="presentation"`, causing assistive technologies to treat them as non‑semantic elements and omit the item from the accessibility tree. Users relying on screen readers therefore cannot hear that a bookmark list exists or navigate to the bookmark.

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Navigate to "Bookmarks" with "Tab" key

### ✔️ Expected result

- The options at the end of the balloon panel should consist only of interactive buttons (no other element types).
- Navigation between these option buttons should be possible only via the Tab key (no arrow-key navigation or other unexpected focus changes).
- When focused (first option), the screen reader should announce: "Bookmarks button"

### ❌ Actual result

- The options at the end of the balloon panel are implemented as unordered list (`<ul>`).
- Navigation between these options is currently possible using the Tab key as well as the Arrow Up and Arrow Down keys.
- When focus is on the first option, the screen reader announces: "List" "Bookmarks button"

### ❓ Possible solution

- Hide the list structure from assistive technologies by adding `role="presentation"` to `<ul>` element.
- Remove arrow key (Arrow Up / Arrow Down) navigation between the option buttons so that navigation is only possible via the Tab key.

## 📃 Other details

Alternative implementation suggestion — if the component is intended to behave like a navigation menu:

- Number of elements = 0: Do not display the area (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` → The button is announced by the screen reader without any list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute → The list is announced by the screen reader as an actual list.
- Navigation to the list should be done via the Tab key.
- Navigation within the list should be possible only via the Arrow Up / Arrow Down keys (not via Tab).
- Pressing Arrow Right should follow the chevron and trigger the selected option.

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The balloon panel that appears when inserting or editing a link contains a list of action buttons (e.g., “Bookmarks”). These buttons are wrapped in a `<ul>` element, causing screen‑readers to announce “List” before each button. This additional, non‑meaningful information disrupts the reading order and creates confusion for users who rely on assistive technology. Moreover, the current keyboard navigation allows the arrow keys to move focus between these buttons, while the expected behavior is to use only the Tab key for focus traversal. This violates the principle that interactive controls should be exposed in a predictable, non‑ambiguous way, leading to a barrier for users with visual impairments.

Users who rely on screen readers hear the extra announcement “List” before the first option (“Bookmarks button”) because the options are wrapped in an unordered list. This unintended list announcement creates confusion and extra cognitive load, and the use of arrow‑key navigation for the options is inconsistent with the expected tab‑only interaction. The barrier impedes efficient access to the link options, limiting the user’s ability to quickly select and activate the desired option.

models.text: The bookmark icon in CKEditor’s edit mode is presented as a decorative graphic, yet it is not properly hidden from assistive technology. This creates a barrier by providing irrelevant or misleading feedback to users who rely on braille or spoken output, thereby impairing the user’s ability to accurately perceive the editor content and navigate bookmarks.

The bookmark icon in CKEditor 5’s edit mode is unintentionally exposed to screen readers. When navigating with the arrow keys, JAWS reads an unrelated string (“et”) instead of the intended bookmark reference or alt text, confusing users who rely on braille output.

models.text: The CKEditor 5 editing interface fails to convey indentation information to screen‑reader users. When a user moves the cursor into an indented paragraph and activates navigation keys (e.g., arrow down), the assistive technology reads the text as if it were left‑aligned, providing no indication that the content is indented. This lack of auditory feedback can prevent users with visual impairments from understanding the structural hierarchy and organization of the document, thereby impeding the effective use of the editor.

Users who rely on screen readers cannot perceive visual indentation changes while editing content in CKEditor. Because the indentation is not announced, they are unable to discern the intended structural hierarchy or grouping of content, which hampers efficient navigation and comprehension.

models.text: The screen reader does not announce the block‑quote element when it is entered in CKEditor 5’s edit mode, causing users of assistive technology to receive no indication that the text is a quotation. This lack of semantic recognition violates the WCAG requirement that content structure be programmatically discoverable, potentially leading to misinterpretation of the content’s meaning.

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/tables/tables.html
2. Place cursor above the table
4. Press the arrow down key (the horizontal cursor becomes visible)
5. Press the arrow down key (the table receives focus)
6. Press the Tab key (the first cell receives focus)

### ✔️ Expected result

- The screen reader user should receive clear infromation about the current position and available actions.

- The screen reader should announce:
   - "insert a line before table <caption text>"
   - "Table with 4 columns and 6 rows"
   - The caption: "Countries that sent their citizen into space"
   - Braille: r1c1 "Country"

The help (Alt+0) should provide a hint that tables can be entered using the"Tab" key.

### ❌ Actual result

- Screen reader output is minimal or unclear:
   - "t"
   - (silence, no output)
   - Braille: r1c1 "Country"

Even when reading the help (Alt+0), the users obtains no guidance on how to enter a table.

models.text: Screen reader users are unable to gain a clear sense of the table’s existence, structure, or caption.  When the table receives focus, the output is either a single “t” or silence, and the caption “Countries that sent their citizen into space” is never announced.  Consequently, keyboard‑only users cannot understand how many rows/columns the table has or how to enter it, violating accessibility expectations for complex widgets.

Users navigating CKEditor in table‑edit mode with a screen reader (e.g., JAWS) receive no useful information when the focus moves into a table cell. The screen reader announces only the cell content, and no contextual details about the table, its caption, or available editing actions are announced. This prevents users from understanding the table structure or how to perform table edits.

models.text: The CKEditor 5 editing area fails to communicate its read‑only state to assistive technology. When the editor is toggled to read‑only, the element with class `.ck‑content` retains an aria‑label that only states “Rich Text Editor. Editing area: main. Press Alt+0 for help.” and omits the “Read only.” cue. This omission prevents users of screen readers or other assistive tools from knowing that the content cannot be edited, creating an accessibility barrier that violates the principle that the functional state of an interface element must be exposed to all users.

Assistive technology users cannot determine that the CKEditor instance is in read‑only mode because the `aria-label` on the editable area does not include the “Read only” status. This omission can lead to confusion when users attempt to interact with the editor and are unaware that input is disabled.

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Load the official demo at https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/feature-rich/
2. Inspect the page and look for the `.ck-body-wrapper` beneath the `<body>` element.
3. Inside of the `.ck ck-aria-live-announcer` container are two `aria-live` sections, each containing an `ul` without any items.

### ✔️ Expected result

The list elements should either be dynamically inserted when there is something to announce or be marked as `aria-hidden` while they do not contain any content.

### ❌ Actual result

The lists exists even if there are zero list items.

This is effectively in violation of [SC 1.3.1](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html) of WCAG 2.2 level A which does not permit empty list elements, since at least one element with the (implicit) `listitem` role is required.

models.text: The CKEditor 5 live‑announcement container (`.ck-aria-live-announcer`) contains two `<ul>` elements that are rendered even when there are no items to announce. According to WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1, an empty list is considered a violation because screen readers will expose a list element with no `listitem` children, thereby providing an inaccurate information structure to users relying on assistive technology. The presence of these empty lists in a live region also increases cognitive load and can result in misleading or redundant announcements.

The page contains an empty `<ul>` inside an `aria-live` region. An empty list violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 because lists must contain at least one listitem to convey meaningful information. The presence of the empty list can cause confusion for users of assistive technology, potentially making the live region appear to provide content when it does not.

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Use the bookmark tool on static text such as a heading
2. Create a link to that bookmark tool

### ✔️ Expected result

The static text that is the destination of the link is missing the `tabindex="-1"` attribute. This is necessary to ensure that all assistive technologies tracking focus can be "moved" to that content. 

### ❌ Actual result

It appears as though the `tabindex="-1"` attribute is absent and the link only relies on fragment navigation (via `href` and `id` matching)

Some assistive tech affected are:
* Windows Screen Magnifier with Keyboard Focus tracking turned on: Viewport resets to the top-left corner.
* iOS 18.3.2/ 17.4 VoiceOver & Safari: Focus is reset to the top of the page.
* iOS 17.4 Full Keyboard Access turned on, external keyboard & Safari: Focus is reset to the top of the page.
* JAWS 2023 & Chrome 124: The page structure is unexpectedly announced starting with the page title. Virtual cursor is then set on the correct content navigated.

### ❓ Possible solution

When we're linking to static content that doesn't already have the `tabindex` attribute, we should add it for the user.

Use `tabindex="-1"` and not `tabindex="0"` nor `tabindex="1"` (or any positive number) to avoid messing up sequential focus navigation orders.

[Does the @tabable/accessible-links node package help?](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabable/accessible-links)

Further reading: https://tab-able.co.uk/inaccessible-links-you-didnt-know-existed/

## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Chrome
* OS: Windows
* First affected CKEditor version: 5
* Installed CKEditor plugins: Bookmark, Link

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The failure to apply `tabindex="-1"` to static bookmark targets prevents assistive technologies from moving focus to the intended content when a link is activated. This barrier causes screen readers and keyboard‑based users to be unaware that navigation has occurred, violating WCAG 2.4.3 and impairing users with visual or motor impairments.

The page fails to move focus to the bookmarked target when activated, causing screen magnifiers, VoiceOver, and other assistive technologies to reset focus to the top of the page. This prevents users who rely on keyboard or focus‑based navigation from reaching the intended content.

models.text: The issue arises when UI elements, such as modal dialogs and toolbar buttons, display identical labels for both the component itself and its associated input field or submenu. This duplication can cause assistive technologies to announce the same label twice, leading to confusion and a higher cognitive load for users relying on screen readers or other assistive devices. Additionally, duplicate labels violate best practices for unique, descriptive labeling, which can impede efficient interaction and navigation.

Duplicated labels cause redundant information for users of assistive technology, making it harder to understand the purpose of each control and increasing the cognitive load when navigating the interface.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Modal dialogs (e.g. "Insert the image") do not have the [`[aria-modal]` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Attributes/aria-modal). We could add it to indicate that these modals are, indeed, modal.

Additionally we could also think about adding the [`inert` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/inert) to the, well, inert part of the page.

models.text: CKEditor 44.3.0 modal dialogs (e.g., image insertion prompts) do not include the `aria-modal="true"` attribute, which indicates that the dialog is modal and that interaction with content outside the dialog should be disabled. Without this attribute, screen reader users and keyboard-only users may still be able to focus and interact with underlying page elements, leading to confusion, focus trapping failures, and a non‑compliant user experience. Additionally, the absence of the `inert` attribute on the background content exacerbates the issue by not programmatically preventing interaction with hidden content.

The modal dialog (e.g., the “Insert the image” dialog) does not declare `aria-modal="true"`, nor does it isolate the rest of the page with the `inert` attribute. Consequently, assistive technology may not recognize that the dialog is modal, and keyboard focus can move to elements behind the dialog. Users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation can inadvertently interact with background content, leading to confusion, lost context, and potential errors.

models.text: The current behavior of the CKEditor menubar causes inconsistent focus management when opening a submenu. When a menu item is activated via the Down arrow key, the focus correctly shifts to the first submenu entry, but when the same item is activated with the Space key, focus remains on the button itself. This inconsistency disrupts the logical focus flow for keyboard‑only users, leading to confusion and reduced efficiency when navigating the editor’s menu structure. The disparity violates established best practices for accessible menus, where focus should be moved into the submenu regardless of the activation method.

The focus remains on the menubar trigger when the menu is opened with the space key, whereas it moves to the first menu item when opened with the arrow key. This inconsistent focus behavior can confuse keyboard‑only users and prevent them from immediately interacting with the menu options, impairing efficient navigation.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

The [Paste from Office feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/pasting/paste-from-office.html) retains heading levels where configuration allows. However, accessibility guidelines mean the [default heading levels](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#heading-levels) start at `<h2>`. If such a config is applied pasting a Word or Google doc will be converted to a paragraph instead.

Ideally the heading levels should be shifted down a level on paste if `<h1>` is not in use.

Such a request was also suggested in [this comment on #2443](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/2443#issuecomment-321299883).

## 📃 Other details
Related issues:

- #2443
- #2455
- #2479
- #10577


---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The pasting behavior removes heading markup when the editor’s configured heading levels begin at `<h2>`. As a result, content that originally used headings in source documents is rendered as plain paragraphs, breaking the document’s logical structure and making it harder for users of assistive technologies to navigate or understand the content hierarchy.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Accessibility dialog makes it possible to organize various keystrokes into categories. Features can define new categories or add to existing categories.

Inside the category, the accessibility dialog presents the registered keystrokes using an alphabetic order. This isn't the best solution, as shortcuts from one group are mixed with completely different shortcuts:

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/1502228/50079928-8687-409e-8b85-880f3c9a1341)

See how bold and italic are mixed with different shortcuts.

I propose to solve it in one of two ways (maybe both?):

1. Provide more categories. Similarly to tables, if there are multiple keystrokes related to one set of features (e.g. text formatting) they can be together. Inside categories we can sort by the order the keystroke was registered, as plugins groups are usually registered one after another, or...
2. Add ordering inside a category through our favourite magic numbers (i.e. `order: 1003` etc.). This will be more difficult for 3rd party developers to manage but gives us more flexibility. If we don't have ordering we may end up having multiple categories, or still have the same problem on a smaller scale.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies may find it difficult to locate specific keyboard shortcuts in the accessibility dialog because shortcuts from unrelated categories are alphabetically mixed. This can increase cognitive load and hinder efficient navigation and use of the editor.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

CKEditor 5 allows for editing alternative text by selecting an image, clicking the alternative text icon, and editing the content of the text alternative field. However, the visible text alternative field is quite small, about 35 characters. This requires the editor to keep what they have done in their head, increasing cognitive load, if they have anything that is longer. I believe a visible field length of perhaps 127 characters would be more reasonable, and it would be even better for the field to expand to fit the entire text alternative content.

Steps:
1. In the CKEditor, select an image (for example, on the [CKEditor 5 demo](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/html-support/), click the red 5 shield.
2. Click the text alternative icon

Expected result: the field is wide (or wide and tall) enough to be able to view a significant amount of text without having to scroll, or better yet, the entire contents of the all of the text alternative field.

Actual result: the field is wide enough to be able to view only about 35 characters, which can be insufficient for a sufficiently complex image. If the text alternative is longer than that, there is no way for the editor to view the entire alternative text at once.

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/3281090/1cc4213e-f7e7-43f0-a0ef-26b3f6d67a11)

While 35 characters may be sufficient to describe the red 5 shield, it is inadequate for an image such as the following:

![image](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/assets/3281090/0e4e06a5-ec71-4299-944d-832cb4b6ddc6)

for which the text alternative is:

> Two images. One shows the rear interior of a Muni bus with yellow poles and blue seats. Above the seats, a four digit bus number "6553" is circled in red. The second image shows the front of the bus. Above the headlight, the number “6553” is also circled in red.


## 📃 Other details

* Browser: Firefox 119.0
* OS: macOS 14.1
* CKEditor version: Whatever is in the demo
* Installed CKEditor plugins: Whatever is in the demo

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

ATM the component shares keyboard support with `SearchTextView`. It's far from perfect because you have to tab first to get access to the list and to browse it. It's unlike any autocomplete out there in the industry. 

The component should have a persistent selection in the text field and up/down arrows selecting (but no focusing) filtered view's items and updating the value of the input. Check out your browser's URL input to get the idea.

This will require:
* Additional stuff in the `FilteredView` interface (for selecting but not turning on or focusing items).
* Keyboard interaction logic
* Undoing some existing focus cycling and tracking logic (I suppose filtered view's items should no longer be focusable).

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any) 1. Paste the HTML from tables 1, 2, 3, and 4 (below) into source view of the [reference implementation of CKEditor](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/html-support/). 2. Switch out of source view and back into it. ### Table 1 This table has a rowgroup header with a colspan. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
``` ### Table 2 This table has two rowgroup headers that have colspans. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
Rowgroup Header 2
Row Header 2 Data 1,2 Data 2,2
Row Header 3 Data 1,3 Data 2,3
``` ### Table 3 Similar to previous examples, but we've removed the colspan on the rowgroup and replaced with empty td elements. We've also added some row headers to the second column and a tbody block that doesn't have any th with a scope set to rowgroup. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Row Subheader 1 Data 1,1
Row Header 2 Row Subheader 2 Data 1,2
Row Header 3 Row Subheader 3 Data 1,3
Rowgroup Header 2
Row Header 4 Row Subheader 4 Data 1,4
``` ### Table 4 This table is an [example from the HTML spec](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/html-support/). ```
2008 2007 2006
Research and development $ 1,109 $ 782 $ 712
Percentage of net sales 3.4% 3.3% 3.7%
Selling, general, and administrative $ 3,761 $ 2,963 $ 2,433
Percentage of net sales 11.6% 12.3% 12.6%
``` ### ✔️ Expected result CKEditor does not alter the table markup. ### ❌ Actual result #### Table 1 CKEditor has moved the parent row for "Rowgroup Header 1" into the thead element, which makes the table inaccessible to screen readers. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
``` #### Table 2 CKEditor has moved all the parent rows for rowgroup headers into the thead element. It has also put all the rows after the thead block into one tbody block. This makes the table inaccessible to screen readers and is a loss of data, since we can no longer reconstruct the original table due to loss of the tbody blocks. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1
Rowgroup Header 2
Row Header 1 Data 1,1 Data 2,1
Row Header 2 Data 1,2 Data 2,2
Row Header 3 Data 1,3 Data 2,3
``` #### Table 3 CKEditor has not moved all the parent rows for rowgroup headers into the thead element, but has put all the rows after the thead block into one tbody block. This causes data loss, since we can no longer reconstruct the original table due to loss of the tbody blocks, and makes the table inaccessible to screen readers. CKEditor has also turned row headers in the second column to td elements with a scope attribute, which is invalid, and causes further accessibility issues. ```
Col Header 1 Col Header 2 Col Header 3
Rowgroup Header 1    
Row Header 1 Row Subheader 1 Data 1,1
Row Header 2 Row Subheader 2 Data 1,2
Row Header 3 Row Subheader 3 Data 1,3
Rowgroup Header 2    
Row Header 4 Row Subheader 4 Data 1,4
``` #### Table 4 CKEditor has added inline styles to col elements (strange), put all the rows after the thead block into one tbody block (again, potential data loss and makes the table inaccessible to screen readers). I'm not sure what the practical implications of this next quirk are, but I want to note it. CKEditor has added a non-breaking space character to an empty th tag. I don't think non-breaking spaces are [ASCII whitespace](https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#ascii-whitespace). This means that the header cell is non-empty and user agents (including screen readers) should add it to the header list for the cells beneath it, according to the [spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#header-and-data-cell-semantics). ```
  2008 2007 2006
Research and development $ 1,109 $ 782 $ 712
Percentage of net sales 3.4% 3.3% 3.7%
Selling, general, and administrative $ 3,761 $ 2,963 $ 2,433
Percentage of net sales 11.6% 12.3% 12.6%
``` ### ❓ Possible solution Add some kind of data attribute that tells CKEditor to not parse the table. Or just follow the [table parsing algorithm from the HTML5 spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/tables.html#table-processing-model). ## 📃 Other details * Browser: Any * OS: Any * First affected CKEditor version: Unknown, but this is happening in the reference implementation. * Installed CKEditor plugins: None --- If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The editor rewrites table markup by moving header rows into the `<thead>`, collapsing multiple `<tbody>` elements into a single one, converting header cells with `scope="rowgroup"` into `<td>` elements, and inserting non‑breaking spaces into empty `<th>` cells. These changes break the table’s header associations, making it difficult or impossible for screen‑reader users to navigate the table or understand the hierarchical structure of row and column headers.

## 📝 Provide a description of the new feature

_What is the expected behavior of the proposed feature?_

--- This feature would make it so that when a user inserts a table, the table automatically has a header row, which is required for [WCAG 2.0 compliance](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/F91.html).

Without a header row and proper `<th>` elements, assistive technologies cannot establish column or row relationships, making the table’s content difficult or impossible to interpret for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive devices.

## 📝 Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)
1. Insert an HTML snippet and type some content
2. Try to reach the "Save changes" or "Cancel" button using the keyboard

### ✔️ Expected result
I expected to be able to move focus into the snippet widget sidebar using a keyboard shortcut. I figured out that `Alt+F10` (or `Option+F10` on Mac) allows a user who is focused on an image widget to enter the image toolbar. I expected this to be the case for the HTML snippet as well. 

That, or hitting `Tab` - but that seems less likely inside an HTML editor since you might expect to be able to indent your code using tab.

### ❌ Actual result

#### Tab key
Moves focus to the next widget in the focus order

#### Toolbar shortcut (`Alt+F10`)
Moves keyboard focus into the main toolbar, not the HTML snippet sidebar

#### Arrow keys
Only moves the cursor inside the snippet editing area

### ❓ Possible solution

context:
## Build good accessibility defaults

A11yFirst has done a good job highlighting how CKEditor could be built more accessibly. Including elements like:
- User guidance on headings
- Support for Language of Parts
- Show blocks (structural elements) & xpath like display
- Accessible tables (headings/caption/summary)
- Support for decorative, informative & complex images
- Separating block structures vs formatting structures
- A11yFirst Help
- Maybe more...  A lot of thought went into this package.

As the [We4Authors Cluster](https://accessibilitycluster.com/) highlighted, many accessibility issues are caused by giving the author more authority than they perhaps require. 

### ✔️ Expected result

- All [demos of CKEditor 5](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/) don't need to include accessibility, but there should be one that does.
- The default install should be set up for accessibility best practices. Most website builders will just use the default, whatever it is -- so make it inclusive by default.
- Setup the [Internationalization Demo ](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/internationalization/)to support the [Language of Parts](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/language-of-parts.html) - good internationalization support isn't just one of many languages, but many combinations of many languages. CKEditor can do this, [so show it](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/language.html#demo).
- Provide support for either [axe](https://github.com/dequelabs/axe-core), or [Editoria11y](https://editoria11y.princeton.edu/2021/03/introducing-editoria11y/) or [Sa11y](https://sa11y.netlify.app/) directly.

### ❌ Actual result

- Well, there aren't a lot of accessibility best practices baked into the demos. 
- There seems to be [support for Abbreviations](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/framework/plugins/abbreviation-plugin/abbreviation-plugin-level-3.html), but not a lot of documentation about that
- [Not sure what this is about ](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/spelling-and-grammar-checking.html#accessibility)"The spell and grammar check is compliant with WCAG 2.1 and Section 508 accessibility standards." 
- "CKEditor 5 provides support for alternate image text" but [what is the default](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/images-text-alternative.html#additional-feature-information)? What about decorative, informative or complex images?
- There's talk of using [CKEditor 5 plugins](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/installation/plugins/plugins.html#common-use-cases) to "Adding semantic value to the content, like annotations or accessibility features." but where are they?
- Thanks for catching the [color contrast issues](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/updating/guides/update-to-35.html#changes-to-the-color-palette-in-the-ui) in the interface "In this release, several changes were made to improve the accessibility and overall contrast of the UI."

### ❓ Possible solution

- There is a great example to build on using CKEditor 4 plugins. Use it.
- Focus on making the defaults accessible and it will benefit everyone
- Check for accessibility early in the development process
- Look for ways to be a best practice authoring tool that is following ATAG 2.0 & following the guidance in the We4Authors Cluster study.

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on CKEditor demos to learn or create content encounter a barrier because the default installation and demos lack built‑in accessibility features such as language of parts, accessible table markup, proper image alternative text handling, and heading guidance. This limitation prevents the resulting content from meeting WCAG requirements for language and structural accessibility.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

We received a report regarding an accessibility issue with how the Heading plugin deals with labeling the different types of headings. This can cause confusion when using a screen reader. Customer's report available below:

>  We are looking at the heading plugin and it's labelling. At the moment the toolbar item is labelled by the currently selected option only, meaning it doesn't provide context for the menu itself, e.g. screen readers read out "Paragraph menu button collapsed sub menu" but doesn't notify the user that the dropdown selector is for heading levels. This can cause confusion to users.
> 
> Something like “Heading level collapsed sub menu” – > “Heading 2 menu button selected” , would make it easier for users to understand the menu they are on, what it does and the selection that is currently active. This would then meet the WCAG AA success criterion 2.4.6 Headings and labels. - Headings and labels provide topic or purpose.

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: The screen reader announces only the currently selected heading level when the heading‑level selector button is collapsed, omitting the context that this button opens a menu for selecting heading levels. This lack of contextual information can confuse users who rely on assistive technology to understand the function of the control.

context:
## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

This improvement is about considering using the [Listbox pattern](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/listbox/) for dropdown buttons, e.g. "Text alignment", "Font family", "Font size" and "Font color" in the toolbar.

Things to consider:

*   Follow the semantics and interactions recommended in the ARIA Listbox pattern. 
    *   For example, for a listbox that functions similarly to a native \<select> element, the Collapsible Dropdown Listbox Example would be the best choice, which uses a \<button> element to trigger a popup listbox element.
*   On the triggering button element: 
    *   Ensure that the element has an id. 
    *   Add an aria-haspopup="listbox" attribute. 
    *   Add an aria-labelledby attribute which references a visible label before the button, and the button itself; this will announce the control label and then the current value. 
    *   Ensure that the \<button> element has an aria-expanded attribute set to "true" when the pop-up is displayed
*   On the list of options: Add a role="listbox" attribute. Add an aria-labelledby attribute, referencing the visible label. Add a role="option" attribute to each option within the listbox.

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on screen readers may not be able to identify the dropdown controls, understand their current value, or navigate the options because the toolbar buttons lack proper ARIA labeling and listbox semantics.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

Take for instance this situation

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1099479/192230840-a88db437-de05-4628-bce7-672e7a950648.png)

Is the "1 of 2" rotator about moving between different annotations (document navigation)? Or is it about moving between totally different features in the context of the same selection (table vs unknown feature)?

The latter (which is table \<-> comments BTW) is correct but it does not change the fact that unless you click it, you'll never learn what is what. And you may not want to click it because you fear that it will move you to an annotation far way in the document or something. 

We need to rethink this UX. We could have tabs there that would clearly say what options are available. Or we could have better labels. I'm pretty sure there's a room for improvement there.

Edit: As a side thought, I suppose the a11y of this solution is also totally broken. 

---

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

_How the feature works now and what you'd like to change_?  
  
**This problem is related to Chrome based browsers only**

NVDA screen reader gives different results in different browsers for toggle buttons:

*   In Firefox it has been properly announcing button names for all toggle buttons e.g. "Bold toggle button not pressed".
*   In Chrome based browsers is has just been announcing "toggle button not pressed" without specifying button names.

We should check whether there is any aria attribute we can add so that names are properly announced for these types of buttons.  
  
\----  
**This problem is related to all browsers**

When dealing with split buttons e.g. bulleted list, highlight or numbered list, the menu part is just announced as "Menu button collapsed sub-menu" and "Expanded" one it is opened. There is no information to which button this submenu belongs to.

We should check whether it is possible to add any aria attribute to improve that.  
The same happens when using JAWS so either this is how it has to be or this is editor a11y problem in general.

\----

**This problem is related to all browsers**

For menu buttons like font family it is not announced when menu is opened. The button is read as "Menu Font-family button sub-menu" but if you press down arrow nothing is announced. 

We should check whether it is possible to add any aria attribute to improve that.  
The same happens when using JAWS so either this is how it has to be or this is editor a11y problem in general.

## 📃 Other details

*   Browser: Chrome, New Edge, Opera
*   OS: Windows
*   CKEditor version: 29.0.0
*   Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

_How the feature works now and what you'd like to change_?

Currently, if an image does not have a text alternative, the `img` element is generated in the data view with no `alt` attribute. According to the HTML spec for "[purely decorative images](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#a-purely-decorative-image-that-doesn't-add-any-information)", and accessibility standards, all `img` elements must have an `alt` attribute, but that attribute should be the empty string `alt=""` when the image does not add any information that would be described in the text alternative.

While the current code maintains an empty alt tag if it is added manually and loaded in through the data view, it does not add the empty alt tag by default to newly inserted images. I think this could be fixed by explicitly setting the `alt` attribute in [insertImage](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/blob/91075a303e5b003b3a82fd96f57a651b6a3c95a9/packages/ckeditor5-image/src/image/utils.js#L82) if it's not passed in - but I'm not sure if that's the best place to do it. I can pass in an empty attribute when I call the insert command, and that will fix this in our editor, but it seems better if CKEditor were to generate accessible HTML by default, without me having to know this.

## 📃 Other details

* `ckeditor5-image` plugin
* tested on v19.0.0

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a 👍 reaction to this post.

This omission can lead to poor experiences for users of assistive technologies and invalidates the generated HTML against current web standards.

## 📝 Provide a description of the improvement

I recently stumbled upon one thing connected to editable focus in CKE5.

So, when the editor is in read only mode, it receives `contenteditable=false` which makes it not-focusable by the browser, as it doesn't have `tabindex` set. This messes up with some features that use editor's `FocusTracker` to operate (I mean focusing annotations for comments and track changes, in readonly mode).

This is not a critical issue for now, but I'd like us to think whether the editor should be or should not be focusable when it is in readonly mode. For me readonly and focusing are different properties. I mean, why should editor be not focusable if it is readonly? For example, for default browser fields, `readonly=true` fields are still focusable.

The easy fix around that is adding `tabindex="-1"` to the editable element when it is in readonly mode. This will not mess up tabbing (tabbing will behave the same as it did in both readonly and normal mode). But it will enable clicking into markers to highlight annotations. However, this is the easy fix solution. Maybe there's more to that issue.

@oleq prepared a fiddle you can play with: [https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/](https://jsfiddle.net/oleq/j6vdsx0q/5/)

models.text: The editor’s read‑only mode disables focus (contenteditable="false" and no tabindex), which prevents keyboard users and assistive‑technology users from navigating to the editor to view or interact with annotations, track‑change markers, or other focus‑dependent features. This loss of access constitutes a barrier to keyboard navigation and content interaction.

## Is this a bug report or feature request?

🆕 Feature request

## 💻 Version of CKEditor

CKEditor v5 @ 12.4.0

## 📋 Steps to reproduce

There's a [Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr9/) which boils down to searching for a first strong directional character and changing the direction of the block, based on that character. Thanks to that algorithm, each block (usually the paragraph) can have its direction (when different than `dir="..."` of the editable), which helps editing mixed content and saving it to the database. It obsoletes the [CKEditor 4 BiDi plugin](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor4/latest/examples/language.html).

* [ ]  It can be implemented using a set of RegExps, which are based on [official BiDi class definitions](http://www.unicode.org/Public/8.0.0/ucd/extracted/DerivedBidiClass.txt). For instance, facebook is using that in [their utils](https://github.com/facebook/fbjs/blob/master/packages/fbjs/src/unicode/UnicodeBidi.js).
* [ ]  The UI of the editor can reflect the direction of the block, e.g. the icons can be mirrored dynamically. [More examples](https://material.io/design/usability/bidirectionality.html).

(extracted from #1151)

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add 👍 to this post.

models.text: The editor’s current lack of proper bidirectional (bidi) support can cause mixed LTR/RTL content to display in the wrong order or with incorrect text flow. Users who read mixed-direction text, including those relying on assistive technologies, may find the content confusing or unreadable, affecting accessibility and comprehension.

## Is this a bug report or feature request?

🆕 Feature request

## 💻 Version of CKEditor

CKEditor v5 @ 12.4.0

## 📋 Steps to reproduce

This idea sparkled during ckeditor5-image#241.

The question how to do that remains open for discussion.

* How should it be displayed?
* Should there be a possibility to adjust height too? Should it be disconnected from width, thus allowing for breaking image aspect ratio?

There are several benefits of adding this feature:

* Users are able to get precise image size without instead of making a super precise resize operation.
* We make the resizer feature accessible.
* Fields can be used to see current image size, without triggering the resizer.

References: https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519117147, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519400868, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519443993, https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5-image/issues/241#issuecomment-519898056

---

If you'd like to see this feature implemented, add 👍 to this post.

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard or screen readers cannot precisely set or verify the dimensions of an image because the current resizer only offers a mouse‑draggable handle with no accessible numeric input. This lack of a focusable, text‑based control prevents users with motor impairments or those using assistive technology from accurately resizing images, creating a barrier to effective content editing.

context:
As discussed in https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/1908 we designed features in CKEditor 5 in a way which helps the users to create accessible content. However, in order to ensure that the content produced by CKEditor 5 is accessible, we'd need a similar solution to [CKEditor 4's accessibility checker](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-4/accessibility-checker/).

---

If you'd like to see accessibility checker for CKEditor 5 add 👍 to this post.

models.text: The absence of an accessibility checker in CKEditor 5 means that users may create content that fails to meet WCAG guidelines (e.g., missing alt text, incorrect heading order, insufficient color contrast). This can result in inaccessible web pages for people with disabilities.

context:
It is possible to navigate through block toolbar items using <kbd>arrow left</kbd> and <kbd>arrow right</kbd> keys. It is possible to close the block toolbar using <kbd>Esc</kbd> or moving focus back to the editable using <kbd>Tab</kbd>. The only missing feature is keystrok for opening and focusing the block toolbar.

![jun-27-2018 20-39-18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1057056/41992948-3784a946-7a4a-11e8-80f0-7954079cc9ac.gif)

models.text: Users who rely on keyboard navigation cannot access the block toolbar because there is no keyboard shortcut or focusable trigger to open it; this limits the ability to use formatting features without a mouse.

context:
The heading rows and heading columns cells[ should have "scope" attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Tables/Advanced#Tables_for_visually_impaired_users) set for accessibility reasons: > Screenreaders will recognize markup structured like this, and allow their users to read out the entire column or row at once, for example. Example proper markup of a table with one heading ```html
a b
c d
```

models.text: Missing or incorrectly applied `scope` attributes on table header cells can prevent screen readers from properly associating header text with the corresponding row or column cells, impairing a user’s ability to understand and navigate tabular data.
